job_title: Desk Assistant
pros: You get to do homework at work, flexible hours because they work around your school schedule, easy if you need a second job, not hard at all, one free meal in taos or the dining place or 50% off anything in the food court, coffee places, and other food places but can only be used once and only on days when you work, relatively short shifts. You can work up to 35 hours, but most prefer 20 or a little less.
cons: You are required to do one graveyard, either weekly scheduled or monthly random graveyards that nobody wants. Still, they are mandatory for the position, weekly mandatory meeting, in-service, dealing with mad parents and spoiled kids all the time, you get no extra pay like they did when I got hired, so graveyards are paid the same as a day shift. You must know everything about the university, including events, because management doesn't tell you anything. There are no keys to the office, so in case of an emergency, you are screwed, and you aren't allowed to eat at work; there is no lunch break either, only when you work past 8 hours in one day. Taxes take more pay now than they did when I got hired. If you want to become a manager you get an insane amount of work for only 50 cents to 1 dollar more which isn't worth it .

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Las Cruces, NM
pros: Love the faculty, staff, and students. Great benefits. Pretty smooth hiring and onboarding process. Growing opportunities for online teaching, creating more opportunities for flextime and work-from-home options. Recent changes in leadership could indicate a positive shift towards more agile decision-making in upper administration. Would recommend to a friend only if they are single, or married without children (or have older children), or if they are already established in their academic career. If they are just starting their career and they have young children (and if they don't have a generous 2nd income from a partner), then they might struggle to stretch the modest NMSU salary and they might get burned out trying to balance family commitments with all of the promotion and tenure expectations.
cons: Upper administration has been in a constant state of change for the better part of a decade, making it challenging to know who is in charge and who is reporting to whom. Upper administration is typically friendly and expresses concern for the well-being of faculty, but they have also been slow to make decisions and do not seem to understand day-to-day experiences and needs of teachers in the classrooms. Problems with turnover and retention, especially among junior faculty. Over-reliance on adjunct teachers, who are also embarrassingly low-paid.

review_title: Amazing student body; poor student affairs division
job_title: Resident Director in Las Cruces, NM
pros:
The students at NMSU are an amazing experience. Coming from the midwest, it was exciting to learn and adapt to these students and their backgrounds, aspirations, and needs. The staff and student affairs persons really care abotu the students here. There is not a single person at NMSU who doesn't want the best for their students. 

The campus is beautiful and everyone is very proud of their state and city and it shows with every person you meet.
cons:
Student affairs is still new at NMSU and the understanding and trust that comes with it are few and far between. Expect to have your knowledge, skills, and education questioned here. It was common to experience animosity when meeting anyone new here. Forming relationships across departments or divisions was very difficult and frustrating. Especially coming from the midwest.
NMSU still hiring Bachelor's degree persons for positions other universities require Masters degrees for. In my experience here it could be for the following reasons:
1. they do not want to compensate monetarily for masters degrees.
2. They do not find value in student affairs therefore do not understand the education we have aquired to be great at our careers.
3. They do not want to treat student affairs as an equal stakeholder at the university.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Las Cruces, NM
pros: Teaching was alright. Depending on what department you are in, you may be working with great faculty.
cons:
University leadership does not care about grad students. We are payed significantly less than students at our sister institutions. You are unable to get tuition waivers, which is unheard of in the hard sciences, so you have to pay the university $5000+/year to employed for $20,000, netting you ~$15,000 if you work through summer. Willing to pay for anything the failing football team needs, but refused to acknowledge grad students needs when asking for a small raise so we don't have to take out student loans for grad school. Also claim that they can't provide any sort of tuition waivers as they are a land grant university, but appear to allow some waiver for faculty family members. 

There were some exclusivity clauses in our grad student handbooks forbidding us to work second jobs if we were a TA, despite the fact we were classified as part-time.

Additionally, during Obamacare rollout, the university had a grad student health insurance program. As part time employees, TAs don't qualify for the employee plan. When grad students were trying to understand whether or not the university plan met minimum requirements, we got the run around (because it didn't). It pretty much ended with a university rep meeting with the graduate student council telling us to lie on our tax filings, and stating we had minimum requirements. 

These are only a few horror stories from being a TA at that institution.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Las Cruces, NM
pros: As a student in engineering/science disciplines, my experience in research work environments has been good; however, you must know/get to know a leading professor or find out who is bringing in the research dollars.  This is especially a big factor in choosing where to go to graduate school of course; don't expect there to be an assistantship there just waiting for you.  A pro resulting from building good relationships with professors, expecting to treat the work like a real job and achieve results, and being willing to ask around other departments for opportunities has been the offer of continuing part time work for a while even after graduation.
cons: The challenge of working here, as a student in engineering especially, can be finding the work in the first place (not guaranteed, especially for grad students).  I find that international students are very often depending on work when they come to school here, but then struggle to find assistantships/jobs in some departments.  It has become obvious to me that international students without connections struggle every semester to survive here due to competition for graduate assistantships and sometimes favoritism on the part of professors.

The pay is not that great but considering that you are doing absolutely nothing it is a pretty good compensation. Would totally recommend the job to someone else.
cons: You are expected to sometimes work weekends or odd hours. The time is not very flexible as you get your schedule picked put for you and not you pick your hours. job_title: Graduate Assistant in Las Cruces, NM
pros:
The opportunity to gain experience teaching and/or working with students, a schedule that mostly works around your classes and other obligations, access to fitness center and eateries.  Also, there are many skilled and helpful faculty members (in addition to those which are not, see below).

I like the Las Cruces, NM environment.
cons:
(1) Favoritism and nepotism is very, very common at NMSU.  Oftentimes, personal issues between permanent faculty over these issues involve their graduate students, at their expense, although it would not be right for me to spell these out here.   

(2) Graduate assistantships seem unfairly biased towards foreign graduate students.  For instance, American grad students are taken off of payroll for about 2-3 weeks during the winter break, whereas foreign students are not.  I also have friends in engineering and math who were denied an assistantship because of a scholarship they had earned competitively (they were US citizens), whereas other non-citizen friends of mine were allowed to keep 30k+ scholarships AND given an assistantship AND given a tuition waiver.  

(3) If you think that senior level administration will help you sort out bureaucratic problems, such as conflicts with other employees and problems with HR/pay issues, think again.  Even if you approach them politely and with the best of intentions, they are hostile and very unprofessional.  To tell you the truth, most of their email correspondence reminds me of flame-war blog postings, not the careful deliberation of an intellectual.

(4) Relatively low salary.  Even the secretaries in our departments make what other secretaries were making in the late 1980's.

review_title: Dysfunctional, ineffective, unethical, corrupt, poor culture for staff
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Las Cruces, NM
pros: Week of Christmas to New Years Day campus is closed which is nice (but they do not enjoy other normally paid holidays that government employees do during the year). Professors do whatever they please including not teaching for 2/3 of the semester, and some salaried employees work off-site at other companies while collecting salaries to work on-campus--even when they are not.
cons: There is no possible way to advance or improve your employment: you will not get a raise, you will not be promoted, you will not be reclassified, and you will likely have to leave the organization to earn fair compensation, so be sure that you take a job that you really want and do not wish to leave.   Administrators do not care about hourly staff and treat permanent staff poorly--the prevailing attitude is that 100 people want your job and you should be prepared to "donate" your time without reward for you efforts.  Reporting unethical and illegal behaviors to management, and even to higher levels will earn only tacit dismissal if not outright retaliation.
